journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part N: Journal of Nanoengineering and Nanosystems

title-group.article-title: Determination of the aggregate fractal dimensions in colloidal nanofluids

article-meta.aff: 2Flat Product Technology Group, Tata Steel Ltd, India
3Presently, Department of Metallurgical Engineering and Materials Science, IIT Bombay, India

author-notes.corresp: Suvankar Ganguly, R&D Division, Tata Steel Ltd, Jamshedpur 831007, India. Email: suva_112@yahoo.co.in

abstract.p: Owing to the significant technological implications of nanoscale colloidal suspensions (nanofluids), it is necessary to develop suitable techniques to characterize the nanostructured aggregates in suspension. In the present work, a fractal dimension approach is applied to characterize the agglomerate structure using image analysis by scanning electron microscope photographs of the nanoparticle aggregates. Aqueous suspensions of aluminum oxide nanoparticles (nanofluids) are used for the study. A simple and direct method of projected image manipulation has been used to calculate the aggregate fractal dimensions in colloidal nanofluid. The fractal dimension provides quantitative information about important morphological features of the aggregate structure. A functional relationship is established between the two-dimensional fractal dimension (df2) and the three-dimensional fractal dimension (df3). The present study demonstrates that the optical image analysis technique can be effectively used for fractal dimension analysis of colloidal nanoparticle aggregates.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: With the advent of nanotechnology in the past decade, production and application of nanoparticles in modern industry has undergone a big expansion. Nanoparticles are made of chemically stable metals, metal oxides or carbon in various forms. These particles, owing to their extreme small sizes (∼1–100 nm) can form very stable colloidal suspensions which are known as nanofluids.1 Such particulate suspensions have often been characterized with augmented transport properties as compared to their bulk carrier phases, thereby leading to significant enhancement in heat transfer and mass transfer.2–4 The possible application area of nanofluids is in advanced cooling systems, micro-electromechanical devices, and in various industrial cooling applications.

Owing to the high surface energy of nanoparticles, coagulation of small particles forming large aggregates is quite common in a suspension of nanocolloids. Agglomeration of nanoparticles and formation of nanoparticle clusters have often been observed in many experimental studies.5–11 Researchers have reported12–15 that nanofluids with large aggregate sizes have higher values of thermal conductivity than predicted by the classical theoretical model.16 Rheological studies showed that enhancements in thermal conductivity of nanofluids are accompanied by increase in viscosity, which may be attributed to the formation of nanoparticle clusters at higher particle volume fraction.17–19 Thus, aggregation kinetics and nanoparticle clustering play an important role in determining the effective transport properties of nanofluids.

The concept of fractals is often used to characterize the aggregate structure in suspension. The fractal theory was first proposed by Mandelbrot,20 a French mathematician. There have been few attempts at modelling the effective transport properties of nanoparticle suspension including the effects of aggregation using fractal morphology of clusters in the suspension.21–24 The inherent stochasticity in the process of agglomeration and break-up of nanoparticle clusters can be well described by the use of fractal theory. Wang et al.21 developed a fractal model for predicting the effective thermal conductivity of dilute suspensions of metallic oxide nanoparticles. Xu and Yu22 presented a model for heat conduction of nanofluids based on fractal distributions of nanoparticles. Xiao et al.23 applied the concepts of fractal geometry and proposed a model for heat transfer of nanofluids which takes into account the effects of convection in the liquid pool. Rheological measurements and models reported in literature19–24 have also utilized fractal theory to assess the effect of particle morphology on the effective viscosity of nano-colloids.

It may be mentioned here that for colloidal aggregates, the most important parameter might be the fractal dimension (df) which allows a quantitative description of the degree of compactness, or openness, of the random aggregate.25 The fractal dimension of compact aggregates has a value close to 3, whereas open aggregates form chain-like structures with a fractal dimension of 1. Several methods for determining fractal dimensions of aggregates have been reported in the literature.26 The electrical sensing method and light-scattering method27–29 are generally used for determining three-dimensional (3D) fractal structure of the aggregate. However, the above-mentioned techniques are mostly used for characterizing biological structures or organic colloids. Measurements of aggregate fractal dimensions in metallic nanoparticle suspensions are very rare. In the present study, a simple and direct method for fractal dimension estimation of nanocolloid suspension has been presented. Based on the principle of image analysis, both two-dimensional (2D) fractal dimension (df2) and 3D fractal dimension (df3) are calculated and a correlation is established between them. Following the present methodology, it is possible to determine directly the 3D fractal magnitudes, without going into rigorous measurements of the 3D parameters, such as volume and number of primary particles in the aggregate, which was otherwise required for computation of df3 values.

sec.title: Methods and materials
sec.p: Commercially available alumina (Al2O3) nanopowder was procured from M/s Degussa AG, Hanau-Wolfgang, Germany. The purity of Al2O3 nanoparticles, in ‘as-received’ condition, was greater than 99.6%, with an average primary particle size of 20 nm, specific surface area (SSA) of 100 ± 15 m2/g (Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET)) and a nominal density of 3.6 g/cm3. To prepare the alumina in water nanofluid of a certain volume fraction, the requisite quantity of nanoparticles was added to de-ionized water and was homogenized by using ultrasonic vibration and magnetic stirring. The dispersion was stable with only minor settling after a couple of days.

The fractal dimension of the nanoparticle aggregate is estimated from the scanning electron microscope (SEM) image. Image analysis can produce useful morphological information of the aggregate structure. In general, image analysis is based on 2D projected images of aggregates obtained from transmission electron microscopy, or scanning electron microscopy. Since image analysis utilizes only 2D projected images, it is difficult to determine df3 requiring 3D aggregate properties such as volume or number of primary particles in the aggregate. However, in the present study, a projected image manipulation technique has been used to calculate the 3D aggregate fractal dimensions in colloidal nanofluid. This is essentially based on the geometric power-law scaling relationships between dimensional geometry and characteristic length scales of the particle clusters. Once established, these fractal dimensions can characterize the mechanical structure, morphological and physical properties of the aggregate.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: This section describes the methodology to calculate the fractal dimension (df2,df3) from the projected SEM images of the clusters, and presents the results obtained from the measurement.

A Zeiss SUPRA25™ SEM with field emission gun (FEG) source was used to image the suspended particles to observe individual particle aggregates. Figure 1(a) shows the FEG–SEM image obtained from the aqueous suspension of Al2O3 particles with volume fraction of 0.005. It can be observed that Al2O3 nanoparticles exist in several clusters with agglomerate size varying within a range of 100–500 nm. Figure 1(b) shows magnified image of particle clusters, which are composed of several individual nanoparticles.

caption.p: (a) Field emission gun–scanning electron microscopy image obtained from aqueous suspension of alumina nanoparticles with volume fraction of 0.005 showing various sizes of nanoparticle clusters. (b) Magnified image of nanoparticle clusters with several individual nanoparticles forming the cluster.

sec.p: A fractal dimension analysis is performed by adopting the method suggested by Forrest and Witten.30 The basic steps for obtaining the 2D fractal dimension (df2) from the SEM image are outlined as follows.

list-item.p: Step 1: A suitable centre point of the cluster is selected.
Step 2: A square with dimension r and the selected point as its centre is plotted.
Step 3: The area occupied by the cluster in the square is calculated.
Step 4: The preceding steps 2 and 3 are repeated for different square dimensions (r) and corresponding area is calculated.
Step 5: Plot r versus area on a log–log scale.

sec.p: For fractal nature of the nanoparticle cluster, the resulting plot is linear, and the gradient of the plot is the fractal dimension (df2).30 Figure 2 illustrates the fractal analysis of the cluster and depicts the result of such analysis for a typical cluster sample. In the present case, the pixels of the image are used for the area calculation (Figure 2(a)). The fractal dimension of the cluster sample is determined, from the gradient of the linear interpolation line, to be 1.75 (Figure 2(b)). The df2 values of the 20 aggregates lie within the range 1.45–1.8; the average is 1.65, with a standard deviation of 0.10 and correlation coefficient (r) of 0.99.

caption.p: (a) Fractal analysis of cluster: selected areas for fractal dimension measurement of a typical cluster sample. (b) Fractal analysis of cluster: relations between length of square and area occupied by clusters. The fractal dimension of the cluster sample is determined, from the gradient of the linear interpolation line, as 1.75.

sec.p: It may be noted here that the 3D fractal dimension is the true representation of the morphological characteristics of the aggregate fractal structure. In order to obtain the 3D fractal dimension (df3) from the micrograph, an image manipulation technique31 is adopted. To achieve this, the SEM image is converted to binary by carefully selecting the pixels, both within the particles and outside the particles, and marking them with two different colours. Figure 3 shows such a representative binary version of an aggregate obtained from the SEM image. The area covered by the cluster is coloured grey while the background has been left white. A circle defining the colloid aggregates is drawn around the particle to include just the aggregates. The total number of pixels in the circle is counted, and the particle concentration in the aggregate (ϕp) is given by the ratio of the number of pixels falling within the particles to the total pixels in the circle. The fractal dimension (df3) is then calculated from the following equation32

caption.p: Binary version of an aggregate from scanning electron microscopy image. The circle defines the colloid aggregates where the area covered by the cluster is coloured grey and the background is kept white. Ra is the aggregate radius.

sec.p: where ϕp is the particle volume fraction in the aggregate, Ra is the aggregate radius and rp is the particle radius.

Based on the data of df2 for several selected cluster samples and corresponding values of df3, a regression analysis is employed to develop a functional relationship between df2 values of projection images and df3 values of aggregates, and the resulting expression is given in equation (2) with a correlation coefficient (r) of 0.76 (Figure 4).

caption.p: Correlation between 2D fractal dimension (df2) and 3D fractal dimension (df3).

sec.p: The error associated with the slope and intercept (Figure 4) are found to be 0.013 and 0.021 respectively, which indicates that the formula works reasonably well for the present case.

Equation (2) physically corroborates the fact that df3 varies linearly and has a fixed relationship with the 2D fractal dimensions df2. Therefore, it may not be necessary to measure 3D properties, such as the volume of an aggregate or the number of primary particles in an aggregate, to compute df3. Owing to the statistical self-similar nature of fractal aggregates,20 the 3D fractal information of different sizes of particle clusters essentially indicates whether they fall under the same group. Therefore, for colloidal aggregates, it is possible to characterize the aggregate structure in suspension from calculation of 3D fractals df3, without going into the measurements of the 3D geometrical properties.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The image analysis method has been used to characterize the fractal structure of nanoscale colloidal aggregates. Aluminum oxide nanoparticles were dispersed in de-ionized water and image analysis was carried out for individual particle aggregates. The 2D fractal dimension of the nanoparticle aggregate was estimated from the SEM image. However, as image analysis utilizes only 2D projected images, it is difficult to determine the 3D fractal dimension, which requires 3D geometrical properties of the aggregate structure, such as volume or number of primary particles in the aggregate. In the present work, a simple method based on a projected image manipulation technique has been used to calculate the 3D aggregate fractal dimensions in colloidal nanofluid. The characterization of these fractal dimensions is essentially based on the geometric power-law scaling relationships between dimensional geometry and characteristic length scales of the particle clusters. The 2D fractal dimension of the colloid aggregates obtained by image analysis exhibits a well-characterized functional relationship with the 3D fractal dimension. The present study demonstrates that by using an optical image analysis technique, it is possible to obtain useful morphological information of particulate aggregates through fractal characterization of the particle clusters.

ack.p: The authors would like to thank the management of Tata Steel Ltd, India, for giving permission to publish this work. The authors wish to acknowledge Mr Vikram Sharma for his help in SEM analysis during the course of this work.
